It’s been a hard day’s night

The title of the song comes from an off-handed comment made by Ringo at the end of a particularly long session in the recording studio. When asked how their progress was coming, he said “It’s been a hard day’s night” (as in, a “a hard day’s work,” except they were working so long it was now nighttime).

The producer found this a catchy quote, and suggested the Beatles write a song around it. “Perhaps something like, ‘It’s been a hard day’s night, until I get home to you’?”

The Beatles mulled it over for a short while and came up with something a little more poetic.

But when I get home to you
 I find the things that you do
 Will make me feel alright

Maureen Cleave, a friend of the Beatles, was there for the conception of these lines. In her own words:

One day I picked John up in a taxi and took him to Abbey Road for a recording session. The tune to the song “A Hard Day’s Night” was in his head, the words scrawled on a birthday card from a fan to his little son Julian: “When I get home to you,” it said, “I find my tiredness is through…” “Rather a feeble line about tiredness”, I said. “OK,” he said cheerfully and, borrowing my pen, instantly changed it to the slightly suggestive: “When I get home to you/I find the things that you do/Will make me feel all right.”



Apparently John was writing the song right there in the taxi on his son Julian’s first birthday card. The birthday card is on display in the British Library.
I should be sleeping like a log

The Beatles were famous for being able to play and sing for long periods of time. As artists, they had incredible stamina. Early in their career they started taking Preludin (An anti-narcoleptic drug that is rarely prescribed today) to help them stay awake and energized.



This infamous picture of the Beatles and the Preludin that fueled many creative nights was a source of mild controversy.
This picture had been taken in 1962 at “The Star Club” by a man named Manfred Weissleder; fearing backlash from the media over an image with drugs in it, Beatles manager Brian Epstein asked him to not release the photographs to any form of media, luckily his words were heeded and the photo wasn’t released until 13 years later in 1975, if the photo had been released earlier on, it could have been harmful to their career.

It’s been a hard day’s night

In the Beatles' case – this refers to the long sessions in the recording studios. Some of their first albums were recorded in marathon sessions.

Ringo’s explanation –

We went to do a job, and we’d worked all day and we happened to work all night. I came up still thinking it was day I suppose, and I said, ‘It’s been a hard day… and I looked around and saw it was dark so I said, ’…night!‘ So we came to 'A Hard Day’s Night.
